verses.text: In those days, the Philistines gathered their armies for war to fight against Israel. Achish said to David, 'You must understand that you and your men are to go with me out to battle.'
verses.comment: Maintains reference to Achish and David’s arrangement; 'go out to battle' aligns with the Hebrew.

verses.text: David said to Achish, 'Very well, you shall find out what your servant can do.' And Achish said to David, 'Very well, I will make you my bodyguard for life.'
verses.comment: Translated 'bodyguard' as literal 'keeper of my head', clarified for modern readers.

verses.text: Now Samuel had died, and all Israel had mourned for him and buried him in Ramah, his own city. And Saul had removed the mediums and necromancers from the land.
verses.comment: 'Mediums and necromancers' used for Hebrew 'oboth and yiddeonim'.

verses.text: The Philistines assembled and came and camped at Shunem. Saul gathered all Israel, and they camped at Gilboa.
verses.comment: Geographical names rendered as in Hebrew.

verses.text: When Saul saw the camp of the Philistines, he was afraid, and his heart trembled greatly.
verses.comment: Literal translation of 'his heart trembled greatly.'

verses.text: Saul inquired of the LORD, but the LORD did not answer him, neither by dreams, nor by Urim, nor by prophets.
verses.comment: 'Urim' left untranslated as per common practice for the Hebrew term.

verses.text: Then Saul said to his servants, 'Seek out for me a woman who is a medium, that I may go to her and inquire of her.' And his servants said to him, 'Behold, there is a woman who is a medium at En-dor.'
verses.comment: 'Medium' represents the Hebrew word 'ba‘alat-’ōb.'

verses.text: So Saul disguised himself and put on other garments and went, he and two men with him. And they came to the woman by night. And he said, 'Divine for me by a spirit and bring up for me whomever I shall name to you.'
verses.comment: 'Divine for me by a spirit' renders the Hebrew idiom literally.

verses.text: The woman said to him, 'Surely you know what Saul has done, how he has cut off the mediums and the necromancers from the land. Why then are you laying a trap for my life to bring about my death?'
verses.comment: Literal rendering of 'laying a trap for my life.'

verses.text: But Saul swore to her by the LORD, 'As the LORD lives, no punishment shall come upon you for this thing.'
verses.comment: Translates the common oath formula 'As the LORD lives' literally.

verses.text: Then the woman said, 'Whom shall I bring up for you?' He said, 'Bring up Samuel for me.'
verses.comment: 'Bring up' is a literal rendering of the Hebrew.

verses.text: When the woman saw Samuel, she cried out with a loud voice. And the woman said to Saul, 'Why have you deceived me? You are Saul!'
verses.comment: The woman's shocked reaction is translated as in Hebrew.

verses.text: The king said to her, 'Do not be afraid. What do you see?' And the woman said to Saul, 'I see a god coming up out of the earth.'
verses.comment: 'A god' renders the Hebrew 'elohim', which often denotes a spirit being.

verses.text: He said to her, 'What is his appearance?' And she said, 'An old man is coming up, and he is wrapped in a robe.' And Saul knew that it was Samuel, and he bowed with his face to the ground and paid homage.
verses.comment: 'Paid homage' translates the Hebrew 'shachah,' meaning to bow in respect.

verses.text: Then Samuel said to Saul, 'Why have you disturbed me by bringing me up?' Saul answered, 'I am in great distress, for the Philistines are warring against me, and God has turned away from me and answers me no more, either by prophets or by dreams. Therefore I have summoned you to tell me what I should do.'
verses.comment: Renders 'disturbed me by bringing me up' as per Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: And Samuel said, 'Why then do you ask me, since the LORD has turned from you and become your enemy?'
verses.comment: 'Become your enemy' follows the Hebrew closely.

verses.text: The LORD has done to you as he spoke by me, for the LORD has torn the kingdom out of your hand and given it to your neighbor, David.
verses.comment: 'Torn the kingdom out of your hand' is literal wording.

verses.text: Because you did not obey the voice of the LORD and did not carry out his fierce wrath against Amalek, therefore the LORD has done this thing to you this day.
verses.comment: 'His fierce wrath' is the literal Hebrew phrase.

verses.text: Moreover, the LORD will give Israel also with you into the hand of the Philistines. And tomorrow you and your sons shall be with me. The LORD will give the army of Israel also into the hand of the Philistines.'
verses.comment: 'With me' is recognized as meaning with Samuel in death.

verses.text: Then Saul fell at once full length on the ground, filled with fear because of the words of Samuel. And there was no strength in him, for he had eaten nothing all day and all night.
verses.comment: Literal phrase 'full length on the ground' preserved.

verses.text: And the woman came to Saul, and when she saw that he was terrified, she said to him, 'Look, your servant has obeyed you. I have risked my life and done what you told me.'
verses.comment: 'Risked my life' is a literal rendering of 'put my life in my hand.'

verses.text: 'Now therefore, please listen also to your servant, and let me set a morsel of bread before you; eat, that you may have strength when you go on your way.'
verses.comment: Literal phrase 'set a morsel of bread before you.'

verses.text: But he refused and said, 'I will not eat.' But his servants, together with the woman, urged him, and he listened to their words. So he arose from the ground and sat on the bed.
verses.comment: Literal 'sat on the bed' as per ancient custom.

verses.text: Now the woman had a fattened calf in the house, and she quickly killed it, and she took flour and kneaded it and baked unleavened bread of it.
verses.comment: Literal rendering, including 'fattened calf.'

verses.text: She put it before Saul and his servants, and they ate. Then they rose and went away that night.
verses.comment: Follows Hebrew word order closely.
